Hey I am thinking about this stuff a bit and.. I wonder if this is 
similar=
 to Novelty Search, where you can choose to have L1 or L2 or 
whatever dist=
ance between phenotype behavior data. 

But in NS usually the behavior data=
 is a fixed space. At the genetic 
level, the genotype space is unconstrain=
ed. Calculating distance 
between points that lie in different spaces is a =
challenge. I even 
wonder if this is possible at all.. 

Take 2 random indi=
viduals from the first generation of a typical NEAT 
evolution and they are=
 all in the same space. Easy to compare. But 
take 2 from the same populati=
on 1000 generations later and you will 
find out they are in completely dif=
ferent spaces. They may all branch 
from the initial minimal space, but the=
 virtual coordinate frame that 
should be able to describe all possible ind=
ividuals does not really 
exist. Or does it? 

In fact I guess it does. I c=
an have a 100000+ neurons fully 
interconnected network and pretend it is t=
he one ultimate space that 
NEAT can search. Then I can assign coordinates =
to genomes based on 
that space. But this is misleading because NEAT effect=
ively discovers 
new spaces during evolution.

So it is a process guided by=
 discovery. Then I guess that genotypic 
distance cannot be calculated more=
 effectively than comparing the 
counts of excess/disjoint genes with respe=
ct of genomes. Assigning 
zeroes to missing links (assuming they exist with=
 0 weight) means that 
these individuals also share genetic history, but th=
ey don't. 

Peter 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <colin.green=
1@...> wrote:
>
> I didn't address this point:
> 
> 2008/12/22 petar_cherve=
nski <petar_chervenski@...>:
> > Suppose that 2 genomes have many disjoint =
genes with respect
> > to each other, if they are both represented as zeroe=
s, this would 
mean
> > they are closer in space?
> 
> Yes that's right. An=
d this is effectively why I backtracked and
> hypothesised that the L1/manh=
attan distance (which is what we are
> effectively using currently) is bett=
er than the L2/Euclidean 
distance.
> I think it would be an interesting ex=
periment to try out thse
> different distance metrics and see some experime=
ntal data to back up
> the hypothesis.
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Colin.
>
